replies.bodyText:
I do not completely agree with this for the following reasons:

It doesn't do any warm to the user as to have it logged has to explicitly enable the debug level for the addon category.
Connect to the database can come from initialization, retry attempts,...
When a user reports a strange issue that is non easily reproducible, asking him to enable trace for the addon category is very useful as you can't debug his machine. I needed it in some difficult bugs in influxdb persistence addon and has been proven to be very useful.
I see mainly all the persistence addons logging when connected, disconnected,...
Finally, although is true that you can have the item status changelog, it's for all the items, isn't it? Having that info only for the addon, and with addon language, it's a valuable information.

Would using trace level will be fine for this?
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText: Leave as is then if it will help fault find for users, as changing it to trace does nothing as most people run at INFO level.
replies.author: Skinah

timeline.bodyText: Does it only change to ONLINE if it connects? if so then remove this logging as it is redundant.
timeline.author: Skinah

replies.bodyText: This is one of the only logs that I left, I hope that it's ok because IMO establishing a connection is very relevant for a DB addon and only is trace level
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText: Since it does not occur very often I don't see it as a big deal to leave as is. If it was once a second, then you would see savings on not having to constantly check if trace was on or off.
replies.author: Skinah

timeline.author: Skinah

replies.bodyText: I fully agree. The error message should be displayed in the UI. That can be achieved by adding it as an argument to updateStatus(). Although, the current error message might not very helpful for the user. Feel free to improve that in a later version.

timeline.bodyText: Same as above. Provide clear and helpful reasons why the error or device went offline if possible and dont log it when the status changes.
timeline.author: Skinah

replies.bodyText:
The same justification as above, I think that connection-disconnection are very important messages, and a very low-level debug category is used.
In case of problems, I think that will be very useful.
replies.author: lujop
fwolter

replies.bodyText:
I see in another logs of the PR that I will remove because they clearly break the rules you linked.
But I think that these logs about connections  in trace are very important ones that don't contradict the rules and will be useful when problems arise.
In fact, I looked at other database/persistence addons and all include those logs.
Any possibility to leave them?
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText:
The way to go is to include the error message as the status detail message in updateStatus().
The state change originated by updateStatus() is logged to events.log. Including the status detail message.
I think that does exactly what you want. WDYT?
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
I see your point and I will remove but I don't agree, I think that mainly all the persistence bindings had logs like this.
And the problem with the events.log is that if you do that way you can't have that relevant debug/trace logs only for an addon, can you?
For me is very useful to ask a user without a reproducible problem clear instructions, like set dbquery category log category to trace and send me the logs.
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText: That's right, the events.log contains the thing status detail messages of all Things.

timeline.bodyText: This is already logged by the framework and can therefore be removed.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: This method is expected to return null if a handler couldn't be found.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
But is that possible that the factory it's called for a binding it doesn't know about?
Usually, I prefer to program that defensively to allow fail-fast behavior
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText:
I think the factory can be called for a Thing type, which doesn't exist.
Fail-fast is good! In this case the framework takes care of it. Returning null is a common pattern in all bindings.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: This will create a new thread each time this method is called and these threads won't be shut down when this handler is disposed. Is there any reason not using the framework scheduler? You can access it via the scheduler field of the super class.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
Thanks @fwolter, I see a big mistake here on my part controlling the future but not the scheduler.
I didn't know about the framework schedulers, is there any documentation about what I can expect from them (sharing, min/max number of threads,...) and what are fair uses for them?
Are ok with large IO operations on edge cases like big connection timeouts?
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText:
The documentation doesn't answer these questions in detail. You may run network operations in the framework's scheduler. Many bindings use 30s for HTTP requests. But in general they should return fast. So, for example Thread.sleep() is a no go.
The number of threads in this pool can be configured by the user, but there's a reasonable default value (which I don't have in mind).
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText:
See above. Use framework scheduler.
scheduleAtFixedRate should only be used if necessary. Use scheduleWithFixedDelay. See https://next.openhab.org/docs/developer/guidelines.html#e-runtime-behavior
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText:
Ok on framework scheduler, but here, the scheduleAtFixedRate is "necessary" because it's the documented and intended behavior.
Possibly an improvement can be to allow the user to setup the fixedDelay behaviour in config.
replies.author: lujop

replies.bodyText: If binding documentation talks about refresh intervals, they use scheduleWithFixedDelay. Usually you don't notice a difference and it makes it a lot easier for the scheduler.
replies.author: fwolter
